Flip bits, not burgers!


Google Summer of Code is a global program that offers students a stipend to write code for open source projects. openSUSE has participated in Google Summer of Code since 2006 and has helped more than 50 students to get started with open source!


Why should I join?

  • Because it's fun! Just like our openSUSE mantra - always have a lot of fun!
  • You will join an international community of awesome and talented developers!
  • You will learn a lot!
  • An opportunity to do work related to your academic pursuits!
  • See how real world software development works!
  • You'll get a t-shirt!

For more information, about the program and who is eligible, please visit the official Google Summer of Code website!

How does it work?

Check if you're eligible for GSoC on the official Google Summer of Code website!

Select one of our mentoring projects or propose one to our Administration team!

Get in touch with the mentor and follow the get started instructions in the project description!

Write an awesome project proposal and submit it to Google Melange!

Code the summer away!

Achieve the ultimate goal!

Where should I start?

Just pick one of our projects and follow the get started instructions:

Nothing you like? Do you have your own idea? Awesome, just get in touch with our team! Creativity and initiative are qualities we highly appreciate.

What did you do in previous years?

Organizer Dashboard for OSEM

Snapper Snapshot GUI

Travel Support Program

This is just a summary, you can find all GSoC projects from 2014 on Google Melange.

Travel Support Program

Mentor: Ancor González Sosa

Mentee: Karthik Senthil

The Travel Support Program(TSP) is a web application, based on Ruby on Rails that has been developed to manage the requests and reimbursements for various conferences such as openSUSE Conference or the KDE e.V. Travel Cost Reimbursement. It is currently being used to manage the openSUSE Travel Support Program, however there is a need for generalization of the design so that other organizations can also start using the application to suit their needs. This is the prime goal of the project.

More Information

Snapper Snapshot GUI

Mentor: İsmail Dönmez

Mentee: Oguz Kayral

Snapper is a snapshot management tool for Btrfs subvolumes and LVM thin-provisioned logical volumes. Currently it is only available as a CLI client and a YaST module. The aim of this project is to create a GUI client for snapper and integrate this client with openSUSE desktop environments.

More Information

Organizer Dashboard for OSEM

Mentor: Henne Vogelsang

Mentee: Christian Bruckmayer

In the FOSS community it’s quite normal to work together with people that are distributed all over the world. Many developers just know each other through the internet. One great chance to meet people you just know so far from the internet in real life are open source conferences. To manage the organisation process openSUSE developed the Open Source Event Manager (OSEM). The goal of this project is to extend OSEM with a dashboard for conference organizers.
